0MMRXfBqfmz4suoIEo1J.description:
**Problem Summary**

Today when an org is created with a custom domain outside of our whitelist public domain list, prospective users are able to auto join an org based on their domain. So a first user setting up Acme Org with their email _Jim@acme.com_ can add people to their org in two ways 1) by sending an invite or 2) by simply sharing the login page and having them sign up. While this provides a very convenient way for **new users** to get auto added to orgs, its been restricting for some of our users who work on 2 or more projects for a different org i.e they may be contractors or have side projects, or have multiple teams in the same org and need to switch between orgs. Therefore someone like Jim with email _jim@acme.com_ can only access a single org and needs to sign up with a new email to create a new org.

Secondly there have been multiple instances where a non-invited user signs up with a "public" domain (e.g. john@gmail.com) - and thus a new org is created for that person - when in fact that user was expecting to be collaborating with someone else (e.g. mary@gmail.com) who had also just signed up to use Tara separately and was already assigned a different org. This necessitated that we remove one of their orgs manually and then let mary@gmail.com invite john@gmail.com so that they can be part of the same org. Being able to be invited to their orgs and switch orgs will eliminate any manual intervention on our part.

**Rollout Plan**

1. Remove autojoin by custom domain. Read more here [https://app.tara.ai/tara-ai/requirement/rmX7TWxCMjykFIh4fNGy](https://app.tara.ai/tara-ai/requirement/rmX7TWxCMjykFIh4fNGy)
2. Convert all views to redux (which effectively removes the local store, which means completing Redux Wave 1 and Wave 2)
3. Start work on the org switcher front-end and back-end implementation using Redux
4. Technical implementation documentation for Org switching is here [https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Multi-Org-Support--AzjbZlUNvd8q0JRDoReU7KR0Ag-9jWxgK9Gk2yobUZV9C1TV](https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Multi-Org-Support--AzjbZlUNvd8q0JRDoReU7KR0Ag-9jWxgK9Gk2yobUZV9C1TV)

**Changing our viewpoint on Orgs**

With some of the user feedback we\'ve been receiving and the more intuitive way of handling the needs of people who want to be able to use multiple org\'s with a single email, we want to move to a concept of workspaces. **While on the backend a workspace is no different than an org.**

Previously we had thought of an org as strongly tied to a single business entity, but moving forward, this is no longer the case. We anticipate that users from the company can and will likely set up multiple workspaces. This definitely makes us more like Slack than Intercom, Jira, Fullstory, etc etc.

This will also lead to a shift in emphasis from focusing on orgs to users as well, where we used focused on the "team" construct as the unit of growth (and at this point, a team is essentially a company because of our market segment), but moving forward our focus will be more on individual users. Ideally we want to capture the user for much longer period, well beyond her tenure at a company, in a way similar to GitHub. We envision a user leveraging Tara for personal projects as well as work items - something that a workspace switcher would encourage and facilitate much more easily. That also means we need to support identifying a single user with multiple email addresses for different workspaces

What it means for our users:

- We\'re shifting our focus from an org/team to the user. Ideally our aim is to capture the user for a longer period, well beyond their tenure at a company, similar to github.
- It lets the user maintain both personal workspace(s) and organizational workspace(s)
- Helps segment work better by letting the switch spaces just like they would on slack (for us this simply means they switch up the workspace url app.tara.ai/acme-org and app.tara.ai/jims-personal
- For larger companies it helps pods and different functions set up their own spaces and gives them the flexibility to define their own work.
- Lets users use a single email to easily log in and switch between orgs they are a part of
- Lets people using contractors and remote engineers set up a secure way of sharing information and switching between workspaces easily.

**Designs**

[https://app.zeplin.io/project/5e5ee71db9ae1b17d524aa55](https://app.zeplin.io/project/5e5ee71db9ae1b17d524aa55)

**Important Backend Changes for Workspaces**

- A user with a single email can now be a part of multiple orgs (our user object is already separated from the org but we need a way to pass org data into the auth so that users can switch between orgs)
- Turning off emailisjoinable and removing redundant logic out of our org creation process
- Let users create multiple workspaces (we may limit this later; we can start with setting a limit of 10 workspaces per email)
- We set restrictions on characters and uppercase support for workspace/org names and validate for that (we only support hyphens for splitting words and we do not support uppercase at all, i.e Tara\_org would be invalid and so would TaraOrg but tara-org would be valid)
- The only way for a another existing user to join a workspace is by an email invitation
- Every new user, who was not invited by someone else, when signing up, Tara creates a new workspace/org. There is no autojoining of any sort on first sign up and a single linear sign up flow for first users regardless. If they do not click through the invitation link then they do not get added to a workspace other than the one created on sign up.
- A signed up user must always have a single workspace
- Create a new object to store workspace logo and workspace name
- Add to above workspace object an activation state so we can let users deactivate a workspace
- Invites are strictly co-related to the org/workspace they are sent from, users accepting an invite have 2 flows: 1) when a user gets an invite and is not a part of Tara he/she is taken to onboarding which removes the create workspace fields; and 2) when a user gets invited to an org and is already an existing member of Tara they get taken to a welcome to the workspace page which confirms on screen they are being added to the workspace and then redirects to new workspace they were added to
- We save the last state of which workspace the user was on so that when they log back in or log in from a new device the user is taken to that workspace

**Important Changes to the front-end**

- Lets users switch between their authorized workspaces
- Let users set up a new workspace even if they have an existing one
- Clear any local storage that user may have throughout different views inside a workspace (this is related to the issues we face today when a user tries to switch orgs, the persisting local state data shows on the org front end)
- Add an area for users to edit their workspace profile i.e for the time being they can change the workspace name and add a logo.
- Soft deleting a workspace if you\'re the admin. Users who want to delete a workspace may be able to deactivate it which will trigger a soft delete on the front end and set a status of deactivated on the backend. When a user deactivates an org they have to double opt in the deactivation, after deactivation the user is taken back to their previous workspace.
- A user can only deactivate a workspace if they have another workspace they are a part of, if the user has one workspace and wants to deactivate it, they cannot do so. They must create a new workspace in order to deactivate another

**Other Items to consider**

When a user is removed from a workspace then his/her tasks remain assigned to them as we are a system of record but the user shows as deactivated in the user list.

We may also need to support identifying a single user with multiple email addresses for different workspaces.

Showing the user workspaces that they can join if they\'ve been invited on their first sign up onboarding

1QuV3amjYXTqIzNM2fMj.author: LCu96CcgYjQz7tEYOi5J1CfMwIv2
1QuV3amjYXTqIzNM2fMj.title: Upload Tasks from Other Applications
1QuV3amjYXTqIzNM2fMj.description:
(**Original doc**: [https://docs.google.com/document/d/1\_hNvB-YU2tvdSswhQjLNUPnThwe2HLI5f7LOdpXmCjs/edit#heading=h.vaaq5t69s1b4](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1_hNvB-YU2tvdSswhQjLNUPnThwe2HLI5f7LOdpXmCjs/edit#heading=h.vaaq5t69s1b4))

**Design**: [https://app.zeplin.io/project/5d82bd8c15ade554f8e9e1c2/dashboard?seid=5e4ec45b1c792c651c79ab6e](https://app.zeplin.io/project/5d82bd8c15ade554f8e9e1c2/dashboard?seid=5e4ec45b1c792c651c79ab6e)

Overview
--------

We are implementing a way for users to upload a file containing tasks that are downloaded from another application such as Trello and Asana.

Key Assumptions
---------------

*   A user can upload the file multiple times, not just during initial set up of Tara.
*   Default operation is Upsert. Tara keeps the original task\'s ID so that if the same task gets uploaded again, the task will be updated
*   Users will only upload tasks that are open - i.e. they are needed to be worked on in future sprints

*   Users are authorized to download data from the external systems.

Sample Exports
--------------

*   Trello Premium Account (CSV) [https://drive.google.com/file/d/1c7gPnMEGkUpCUAQLSfBlP4AWGDGJ6er3/view?usp=sharing](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1c7gPnMEGkUpCUAQLSfBlP4AWGDGJ6er3/view?usp=sharing)
*   Asana (CSV) [https://drive.google.com/file/d/1e\_c5LUuV2geK0JevwjcOF\_E7RscSXZ8c/view?usp=sharing](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1e_c5LUuV2geK0JevwjcOF_E7RscSXZ8c/view?usp=sharing)

*   **OUT of SCOPE**: We shall not support the JSON output from Trello\'s free account. For reference, here\'s an example of the data: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Mhu87mH\_SHuc-9PJILsqakDsxHx6zhtR/view?usp=sharing

Data mapping
------------

The two Tara attributes that will be mapped:

*   Task Title: Trello\'s "Card Name" attribute and Asana\'s "Name" attribute
*   Task description: Trello\'s "Card Description" and Asana\'s "Notes" attribute
*   Other data that are in the CSV should be captured. In particular, we should capture the unique ID so that we can use it to reference tasks that are created from the import and do proper upserts

Outstanding questions / details to flesh out
--------------------------------------------

1.  We should keep the entire record for future remapping
2.  Size restriction: max <**XXX>** tasks
3.  The newly created tasks from an uploaded file will be found in the General Backlog. (Alternate solution: create a new requirement for that import and put all the newly created tasks there; but then we should decide how to manage a task that was already previously uploaded)
4.  Show a spinning wheel (or progress bar) during the upload

Implementation
--------------

Import is done in two steps:

1\. Upload file to Firebase Storage (under \`orgs/${orgId}/imports/${serviceName}${uuid}.csv\` path) and receive filename in response.

2\. Send a request to callable function (importFile) with the following payload:

{

filename: string (UUID),

serviceName: string (e.g. trello),

organizationId: string (e.g. tara-ai)

}

This function parses CSV file and writes each line as is (serialized as JSON) to \`orgs/{orgId}/imports/{importId}/lines\` collection.

Structure of Import document:

items: sub collection

totalItemsCount: number

processedItemCount: number

status: \'pending\' | \'ok\' | \'error\'

Structure of ImportItem document:

data: string (raw representation of CSV line in JSON format)

service: \'asana\' | \'trello\'

status: \'pending\' | \'ok\' | \'error\'

errorMessage: string | null

taskId: string

Both collection are not readable from frontend (via security rules).

Each write to ImportItems collection triggers another function (processImportItem) that converts incoming line into Tara task.

Task interface should be extended:

export type ExternalIssue = GithubIssue | TrelloIssue | AsanaIssue;

export interface TrelloIssue { service: \'trello\'; boardId: string; cardId: string;}

export interface AsanaIssue { service: \'asana\'; workspaceId: string; taskId: string;}

2TMWOn2rD3k9ssFiUsPd.author: 7PVaq3IAtSh9fwMMdyQZ7Cp0Fm33
2TMWOn2rD3k9ssFiUsPd.description:
**Objective:**

​

Support custom effort units throughout workspaces. A new or current user on tara should be able to change their effort unit on their workspace from the workspace settings page.

The effort units we would like to support are:

- Days **(Always on by Default for all workspaces)**
- Story Points
- Hours

​

Changing an Effort Unit for a workspace will do the following:

- It will update the unit label inside every task card
- A workspace can only choose between one unit at a time
- The sprint load indicator will reflect the effort unit change immediately for the current sprint but not for previous sprints, there is no conversion involved
- ~~Previous sprint data and effort units should not be affected by changing the effort unit. If user had completed Sprint 1 and 2 in hours and for Sprint 3 they decided to move to days, then Sprint 1 and 2 when looked at from the Sprint details page would show hours (This is a stretch goal, you may not need to do this if it seems difficult)~~ Refactor spec in https://app.tara.ai/tara-ai/tasks/1960 to have effort as a workspace-level setting.
- Since the home page, overload indicator and anywhere where total efforts are calculated doesn\'t really show the unit for the effort completed and total effort it would not be affected

2hAj0lj88FtsSuUbrITO.author: LCu96CcgYjQz7tEYOi5J1CfMwIv2
2hAj0lj88FtsSuUbrITO.title: Prioritization of tasks and requirements: drag and drop reordering
2hAj0lj88FtsSuUbrITO.description:
# Overview

The ability to prioritize and sequence which tasks and requirements to work on for the team and for each engineer is critical to drive towards the project end goal efficiently. A common way to organize tasks in priority order is by ordering the tasks top to bottom, where the top ones are deemed more important, and thus should be worked on first. In this requirement, we outline how we will implement drag and drop reordering of tasks and requirements across the application.

​

# Requirements

## Current iteration: reordering of tasks on sprint pages

++Req 1: Reordering of individual tasks++

A user should be able to move a task up and down the list of tasks in the following places:

1. within a sprint column
2. within a requirement bin on the backlog
3. within sprint timeline
4. within a requirement on the requirement detail page - [design](https://app.zeplin.io/project/5fc5615ee26203b804210c21/screen/5fd1b1d813c1034f6b6465af)

​

A user should be able to select multiple tasks and move them as a group up and down a list (when multi-select is enabled)

​

Page level filter/sorting should still work but it will disable drag and drop. Page-level filter/sorts do not persistent when the user navigate away. **- BS:12/7**

​

++**Technical Specs**++** - BS:12/7**

- Add a property to sprint & requirements called \`ordered: TaskId[]\`.
- Since order is important we do NOT use fieldValues for union/remove.
- Any change to the ordered field must be in a transaction with all the ids added/remove from the list.
- A selector should be created to maintain the order of the tasks for the doc. As long as the property name is the same if can be used for all ordered tasks.
- To avoid jumping when dragging and dropping first:
- attempt to use firestore optimistic commits first via \`.onSnapshot({includeMetadataChanges: true}, callback)\` It\'s possible that it can sync with the React render cycle
- If that doesn\'t work using a local Redux Slice to hold state should work.
- Let\'s try to keep from adding any band-aid to directly to React because it will be flakey.

​

​

++Req 2: Preservation of order across the app++

1. Order should be preserved on the workspace level
2. Order should persist even after logout and relogin
3. Order should persist across pages/modules. For example, if a user reorders the task list on the sprint plan page, that order should be used for the sprint timeline, as well as the homepage.

​

++Additional specifications++

1. For this current iteration, changing task order on a sprint column does not change the order of tasks in a requirement
2. Similarly, changing order of tasks on a requirement would not change the order of tasks on the sprint
3. When tasks are moved from one list to another, if the move is performed by drag and drop, the user can drag the tasks to the desired location on the new list directly. If the move is not done by drag and drop (e.g. changing the sprint assignment attribute on the task), then those tasks will be surfaced at the top of the new list
4. In a view where a user can sort the list differently, that sort is only done temporarily and would not affect the user-defined order

​

Designs:

\* task list in requirement

\* task list in sprint timeline

​

​

`Type ReorderAction {`

`ids: Data.TaskId[];`

`after: string | "HEAD";`

`}`

`type TaskReorderSprint = Pick<UITask, \'sprint\'> & ReorderAction`

`type TaskReorderRequirement = Pick<UITask, \'_relationships.requirement\'> & ReorderAction`

`type TaskReorderSubtask = Pick<UITask, \'_relationships.parent\'> & ReorderAction`

​

`Export type TaskReorder = TaskReorderSprint | TaskReorderRequirement | TaskReorderSubtask`

​

​

​

# A preview of future work

Future iterations will include reordering on other pages

## Iteration 2: reordering of requirements page

1. User should be able to reorder task in the requirement details page
2. In this iteration, changing the order of the task in the requirement will effect any order changes elsewhere.

​

## Iteration 3: reordering of requirements

1. A user should be able to move requirements and up and down the backlog list.
2. User should be able to move each requirement up and down the requirement list table
3. Order should be preserved across backlog and requirement list

​

## Iteration 4: reordering on homepage

1. User should be able to reorder task list on the homepage (focus state)

5jvPOQzc8iJQFPUvfDrT.title: INTEGRATIONS: GitHub improvement round 4
5jvPOQzc8iJQFPUvfDrT.author: LCu96CcgYjQz7tEYOi5J1CfMwIv2
5jvPOQzc8iJQFPUvfDrT.description:
This requirement captures the second part of work from GitHub improvement (First part here: https://app.tara.ai/tara-ai/requirement/ehPRwkk9ck4O0IaYelDV)

​

**Functionalities**

1. ++Let user find imported issues easily based on repos++. Today, all imported GitHub issues are put in a single GitHub bin in the backlog. The problem is that they are not organized by repos, which are the logical separation that is already created on GitHub side. Users should be able to find tasks easily based on the repos. One solution is to expose the GitHub meta data for searching and filtering in Tara (e.g. repos, labels), especially in the backlog. This will be tackled as part of filter-search capability.
2. ++Make GitHub issue import optional++. Currently Tara imports GitHub issues by default, but the reality is that many orgs care more for the Tara Task to Git data linkage. We should make the issue import optional. (Design: https://app.zeplin.io/project/5d82bd8c15ade554f8e9e1c2/screen/5f7e4ad571c08355f8cf4204)
3. ++Option to create GitHub issues from Tara tasks++. Today, only GitHub-created issues are imported. When Tara tasks are created, they are not exported back to GitHub. We have had multiple requests to close this part of the loop.
4. ++Capture deployment/environment information++.
5. Synchronizing comments with GitHub (make it a default option that a user can disable, much like user can choose whether to show Slack thread in the main channel feed)

​

**Out of Scope**

1. ++Standardize/strongly encourage the task-git linkage based on branch.++ Today, a user can link PRs, commits, and branches to a task by using the TASK-ID. However, if the user links by branch, then the commits and the PRs come for free.
2. ++Option to automate task lifecycle++. This is one of the most compelling reasons for linking up Git data with tasks. This will eliminate the need for engineers to manually update task statuses. Some users even describe this as "magical" because there will be no more ambiguity about progress. The automation will be based on: 1) branch creation moves associated tasks from "To Do" to "Doing", and 2) PR closing moves tasks from "Doing" to "Done". (see Open Questions regarding customization or adding additional statuses)
3. Synchronizing labels with GitHub
4. Convert check lists into subtasks
5. Tie branch, commits and PRs at the subtask level
6. Tie branch, commits, and PRs at the requirement level

This requirement captures the initial functionality for our slack application, to be rolled out as an unlisted app to our existing users.

​

Version 1 will enable existing Tara users and teams to receive notifications on comments and mentions, when a new requirement is created. Also they will be able to view previews for URLs to tasks and requirements. Version 1 enables current and existing users of Tara to view information around a task or requirement.

​

​

​

![image](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/tara-cloud.appspot.com/o/orgs%2Ftara-ai%2Frequirements%2F6eNbU2s88d09FAy1RkII%2FSnip20201029\_20-bfc0decb-fe84-4870-825d-6f4d9ff76eb5?alt=media&token=adba09ee-b2d1-472a-b4d5-f0fa2aec49c2)

​

​

# Planned:

Week of Oct 19th, internal testing.

Oct 26th: roll-out to Tara teams through integrations page

App submission date: TBD

​

Version 1:

- Connecting Tara and Slack
- Previews (for tasks and requirements) and
- Notifications for comments and @mentions (Current functionality, you get a notification when someone some adds a comment to a tasks, it happens when you are assignee, author or collaborator or when someone mentions you in comments. We DO NOT have notifications when someone mentions you in a task or requirement description)
- Activate slack integration on our integrations page

​

++**Version 1:**++

​

With the Tara Slack app, users should be able to:

​

- May need onboarding screen after the user activates the bot
- Connect their Tara profile and slack profile upon on-boarding:

7GX005xAU24K5GORE7i4.description:
## Overview

Overall goal is to enable a lightweight integration with GitLab to tie git statuses to Tara tasks.

The project will be divided into multiple phases. ++Phase 1 is to capture MR information only.++

​

## Requirements

1. Integrations page update: a user should be able to generate a secret and copy the HTTP endpoint for a particular workspace to configure the webhook in GitLab. This part of the UI will be contained on the integrations page. The user should be able to a) generate a secret or regenerate a secret and b) be able to access their workspace assigned unique webhook. For the time being just like the github integration the only users allowed authorize and use webhooks will be admins of the workspace
2. The webhook endpoint for the workspace should follow the same structure as the workspace URL, so for example https://app.tara.ai/webooks/gitlab
3. Capture all the Merge Request (MR) and Push events data sent from GitLab. Create and update a PR summary document for each MR from GitLab. Below are all the events that can be sent over the webHook. You can read more about the payload https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/integrations/webhooks.html

​

​

![image](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/tara-cloud.appspot.com/o/orgs%2Ftara-ai%2Frequirements%2F7GX005xAU24K5GORE7i4%2Fimage-6ff833a0-f4b9-4c9d-972b-72a56ef2f8f8?alt=media&token=7ee94e56-d119-4aa6-9d72-7173f084e2d2)

​

1. Tie MR to task when the MR title has TASK-XYZ and show MR information on the Sprint Timeline per this requirement (https://app.tara.ai/tara-ai/requirement/ehPRwkk9ck4O0IaYelDV
2. Update UI through the app to accommodate for GitLab integration - Homepage PR table, task card icons, sprint progress timelines, PR tables, etc
3. [Please check with Derek] Feature flag for specific workspaces so that we will have select early users use this to ensure the integration works well. Candidate workspaces: altoira, spleet, kivky, krowd-it. Expectation is to have this run for 1 to 2 weeks.

​

## Secrets

1. V1 will use a cloud function that will fetch an existing API Secret or generate a new one if none if found
2. Only admins for the workspace will be able to see the secret
3. The secret will not change for v1
4. There will be one secret per workspace and it will be be stored in the integrations collection

​

## Data Mapping

1. Map the MR data to the PR fragment collection, so that the data can be shown on the task modal and the sprint progress page as it does for GitHub PRs. This should follow the same pattern we have for GitHub.
2. Webhooks are only one way, so our application will only receive data from GitLab and will not send any updates to GitLab
3. The payload structure for Gitlab is different from Github at a glance, while the field names are the same there are extra objects in the payload. For our case, the main ones we need to grab for Gitlab are the same on Gitlab. I will leave it up to the engineering pod to decide whether they want to save the whole payload or only parts that are useful.

​

For example, the following mapping shows the main fields on GitHub (Pull Request Payload) and Gitlab (Merge Request Payload)

​

Github == Gitlab

title == title

state == state

assignees == assignees

​

Objects that are different

Gitlab handles the source and target objects differently in their Merge requests. Whereas GitHub uses diff URLs. You can see the payload compared between the two by visiting the links

​

Gitlab: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/integrations/webhooks.html#merge-request-events

Github: https://docs.github.com/en/free-pro-team@latest/developers/webhooks-and-events/webhook-events-and-payloads#pull\_request

​

## Questions and Considerations

1. [Q] Can a workspace have both GitHub and GitLab? [A] Technically yes, and our system should be able to handle that. The edge case is that somehow a user erroneously tag a GitHub branch/commit/PR as well as GitLab branch/commit/MR with the same TASK-ID, but this should not really happen in real life.

​

## Out of Scope

1. Import issues
2. Delete action
3. Synchronization with source system; if there are changes on Tara, the updates will be sent back to the source system
4. Sync with users

​

## Acceptance

1. An Admin user is able to go to the Integrations page, copy the secret, and URL to set up the GitLab webhook.
2. When an MR on GitLab that has a TASK-ID on the title is created, a user is able to see the MR tied to the task on the task modal.
3. Using Google Analytics, we should be able to track - via data-cy tags - when a user clicks on "Connect" on integrations page, click the copy icons of the URL and secret, and other elements that the user can interact with.

​

## Implementation

**Installation flow**:

1. The user clicks "Install" or "Generate new token" or somehow initiates the installation (only for Tara Workspace Admins)

​

1. FE calls `/setupIntegration` CF and receives **secretToken** in return
2. 2.1. BE creates new **GitlabIntegration** document with newly generated **secretToken**
3. 2.2. onWrite trigger creates the denormalized **GitlabIntegrationPreview** on the Organization document

​

1. FE displays the **secretToken** along with the **GITLAB\_WEBHOOKS\_URL **(taken from environment variables)
2. The user goes back to Tara and clicks "Done" or sth. The FE will always show Tara Workspace Admins the same API key. It will never change for v1. Each workspace will have a their own key.

​

Initiating installation should create a new GitlabIntegration document

​

Collection: _orgs/{orgId}/integrations_

`type GitlabIntegration = GenericIntegration & {`

`service: \'gitlab\',`

`secretToken: string,`

`}`

​

The denormalized version of this Integration should be created on the Organization document:

​

`type GitlabIntegrationPreview = {`

`service: \'gitlab\',`

`id: Data.Id.IntegrationId;`

`}`

​

​

​

7GX005xAU24K5GORE7i4.title: Gitlab Inbound API/webhook: Phase 1

For the shoot next Wednesday, we\'re looking to create a keynote-style video. Below I\'ve listed bullets for what everyone\'s talking points should include, in the order which they will appear.

​

Feel free to include anything you feel is important or relevant, as long as you can keep it within the time frame. Also remember to bring you rlaptops.

​

Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns!

​

## Iba (2 mins)

- Tara\'s mission & vision
- Who we\'re building for
- Growth in the last year - response from 1.0
- 2.0 - high level what\'s being unveiled and why

​

​

## Syed (2-3 mins)

- The team we\'ve assembled to tackle this problem
- How we\'re pushing the envelope with 2.0, and setting the stage for automation/co-pilot
- Github sync, Slack app

​

## Cisco (2 mins)

- What we heard from customers
- Unveiling the newly designed Work Drawer
- Newly designed task pane (on the right)

​

​

## Bobby (2 mins)

- Performance & speed as a feature. How we\'re building Tara to function like a native app.
- Instantaneous feedback (faster load times, and overall app\'s performance)
- 1 point on infrastructure

​

## Iba (1 min)

- Outro? Git ship done. The most powerful free platform in project management, and one note on "premium workspaces."

​

Generate unique invite links based on workspaces. Invite Links will allow any user to who the link is shared with to sign up on the platform. They should be time sensitive and should expire in either 1 day, 7 days or 14 days depending on what the user chooses. They will place the user within the workspace and the admin user can later decide which teams to add them too.

​

When a new user first signs up we created the first invite link valid for 14 days and it is sent with the users welcome email. <--- [ @tara-user-o4yyzJztJzg546ggMrWBjMX2dyw2 I\'d suggest setting the default to a shorter time - 7 days max, to give users a sense of stronger security...]

​

Constraints:

A workspace can only have one unique invite link per time period per workspace. So if a user selects 7 days validity, they get a unique url for that 7 day link. If a second user clicks on copy link in the invite modal they get the same link that was previously generated.

​

Invite link structure:

{workspace\_url}/join/shared\_invite/{unique\_alphanumerical\_22\_character\_id}

​

When the user reaches this invite page they are presented with a welcome message and the auth options to sign up at the bottom. Designs will be provided.

​

This requirements requires changes to the following areas:

- Invite Modal

​

Following new UI to be introduced:

​

**Discussions:**

​

Q: When a new user first signs up we created the first invite link valid for 14 days and it is sent with the users welcome email. <--- [ @tara-user-o4yyzJztJzg546ggMrWBjMX2dyw2 I\'d suggest setting the default to a shorter time - 7 days max, to give users a sense of stronger security...]

8uAlXAzmOcbpYC3SvMXf.author: LCu96CcgYjQz7tEYOi5J1CfMwIv2
8uAlXAzmOcbpYC3SvMXf.title: Human-friendly TASK ID
8uAlXAzmOcbpYC3SvMXf.description:
Background
==========

A Tara task represents a fundamental unit of work, and one of the primary goals of Tara is to enable teams to accomplish as many tasks, and as efficiently as possible. Being able to easily reference and discuss task details is fundamental to the software development workflow.

Requirements for Task ID
========================

1.  Human-friendly, easily referenceable in texts, PRDs, other tasks, as well as API parameters
2.  Each task ID in Tara has to be unique within an organization

Core Use Cases
==============

1\. **Referencing tasks in commit messages, PRs branches**: in the near future, we will enhance the task object to capture commits and PRs that are tied to the task. We shall enable a user to directly and automatically link branches, commits, and PRs by including the Tara Task ID in branch names, commit messages or pull requests title.

2\. **Directly sharing tasks by URL**: users can easily share tasks by referencing the TASK-ID. For example sharing a URL (either [https://app.tara.ai/tara-ai/task/246270](https://app.tara.ai/tara-ai/task/246270) or [https://app.tara.ai/tara-ai/task/TASK-246270](https://app.tara.ai/tara-ai/task/246270)[](https://app.tara.ai/tara-ai/task/246270) - let\'s discuss)

3\. **Reference a task within Tara**: in the future we may recognize that TASK-23461 in a description is a Tara task and thus converts it into a link (much like how Jira works with Jira issues). Also task IDs will be shown along side the list of PRs, commits that are linked to those tasks in the appropriate areas of the application.

Solution / Spec
===============

Note that there is a plan to also add human-friendly IDs for requirements for the future, and therefore, for tasks, we will use the convention TASK-XXXXXX. The XXXXXX part of the task ID will take o numeric sequence of up to 6 characters. Each task created is automatically assigned a unique ID sequentially generated within each org, starting from 1 to 999999. Thus, for each org, there should be approximately ~1 million unique IDs available. Example IDs for two tasks: TASK-6272 and TASK-467189.

(Note: in the future requirement ID may take on a format like REQ-7278.)

From David:

Additionally, engineers may want to use short codes like T235, R1235, and I4636. When we have a native app we can support URIs like tara:t/235 (with expanded forms as well of course)

**Security Considerations**
===========================

*   The Task Paths needs to be protected so for example Org Tara and Org Google can have the same Task Reference /tara-ai/task-232 and /google/task-232, a user should not be able to manipulate the URL\'s to gain access to another orgs tasks.
*   The tasks need to 1) belong to a single org 2) the creator of the task must belong to the same org 3) When the task URL is shared it can only be accessed by logged in users from that org

Implementation Plan
===================

See this doc: [https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Human-friendly-Task-ID-generation-li3IyA82uu8BBjWyi1lrR](https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Human-friendly-Task-ID-generation-li3IyA82uu8BBjWyi1lrR)[](https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Human-friendly-Task-ID-generation-li3IyA82uu8BBjWyi1lrR)

A5SNF8zbXkhPLeecyVtI.title: Notifications [Draft]
A5SNF8zbXkhPLeecyVtI.description:
Draft requirement to store possible updates to the notifications feature for slack and the overall application- separating this from the slack app requirement as it needs more scoping work to allow for notifications across the app (requires settings, email notifications and slack notifications.

​

- New notifications relating to: new tasks, requirements, sprint completion, tasks marked as done.
- Set preferred notifications for personal and channel based notifications on tasks, sprints, requirements, comments and mentions.

​

## ++Notifications++

[See designs here](https://app.zeplin.io/project/5f8dbfcc26d46e60137620ec)

Additional notifications for public channel and private notifications from Tara. Notifications require a settings page in Tara -> user should be able to configure which notifications they want to view and see in slack.

_Categories of notifications on Tara:_

_Public channel, (channel) vs private notifications (App DM)_

_Requirements:_

- When someone creates a requirement (channel)
- When someone mentions you in a requirement (App DM)
- When all tasks in a requirement are marked as done (channel - optional for v2)

_Tasks:_

- When a task I\'m collaborating on or assigned to, changes status (App DM)
- When I\'m newly assigned to a task (App DM)
- When I\'m newly added as a collaborator to a task (App DM)
- When I\'m mentioned inside a task (App DM)
- When a task changes status (channel - optional for v2)

_Sprints:_

- When a sprint is completed (channel): send notification on PRs, commits, tasks and effort completed.

_Comments:_

- When there is a new comment on a task I\'m assigned to
- When there is a new comment on a task I\'m collaborating on
- When someone mentions me inside a comment

 > Note: We should have notifications set by default, which users can toggle in settings inside Tara.

 > ​

![image](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/tara-cloud.appspot.com/o/orgs%2Ftara-ai%2Frequirements%2FNCBW1wpzUJUQzQYqdnO3%2Fimage-4a3207f9-7c7f-4d0a-89ce-e10c37a3d591?alt=media&token=b9c2c20b-895f-4ad7-a1b4-efa3726efa08)

## ​

​
A5SNF8zbXkhPLeecyVtI.author: u83CGZwusdaS32hkaTjThNrASeA3

A8Vl4FLKAw2tsTSPc04l.description:
The Clojure environment requires multiple items for a stable infrastructure and ease of development.

​

## 1. Clojure foundation + offline Firebase.

Devs should instantly get a full offline environment up be able to switch to dev, staging or prod environments.

They should run a command like `clj -A:dev` and have a full environment up.

- boots up repl to use for VS Code or Emacs
- launches the NodeJS VM
- boots the local firestore emulator, pubsub emulator and auth emulator
- Firestore is loaded with valid data generated from JSON-Schemas
- Auth emulator creates a single user called dev@tara.ai with a password of Password1!
- The auth user\'s email address needs to be set to validated and claims setup to access the offline Firestore documents
- I use figwheel in node but we could just have the VSCode Clava and Emacs integration setup

​

## 2. GCP wrappers.For the basic system we want to abstract away the GCP infrastructure.

- build a basic component system
- **firestore wrapper** should be able to query data, batch saves and run transaction. The public interface should be normal EDN data so that it\'s serializable. The idea for the query syntax would be:

(firestore/query{:path :org/some-org-id/some-collection-type

:id "some-document-id"

:order [:date :desc]

:where [[:date ">=" (t/minus (t/now) (t/months 2))] [:date "<=" (t/now)]]

:limit 2000})

It should support all query options on the firestore [Query API](https://firebase.google.com/docs/reference/node/firebase.firestore.Query)(endAt, endBefore, limit, limitToLast, orderBy, where, startAt, startAfter) are the fields we should support. The return should be pure edn objects where each hash-map in the list include everything from the .data() method along with a :path and :id property to store the database context. There is a small item about how to handle dates. Internally Firestore used timestamp objects that contain a seconds and nanoseconds. We could use that, wrap as a native date or using cljs-time. Personally I prefer to lazily convert them to cljs-time dates in the UTC timezone.

Writing should provide a cleaner interface on the [Firestore.batch API](https://firebase.google.com/docs/reference/node/firebase.firestore.WriteBatch). We should be able to collect any number of documents into a batch. Internally Firestore batches have a max limit of 500 documents. We should support multiple batches and be able to execute them together. The return of calling would be a thunk that can be executed later. I could also see this as a channel or stream for batching saves.

(firestore/batch[{

:path :org/some-org-id/some-collection-type

:id "some-document-id"

:action :UPDATE ;; or :DELETE :CREATE

:payload some-document}])

[Transactions](https://firebase.google.com/docs/reference/node/firebase.firestore.Transaction) is the last item to support. Initializing a transaction will return an instance that can be used to query, get a single document or write multiple documents. When the transaction is committed it will run all on the db. Ideally it has an interface of EDN as well so we\'re not passing around objects. But I haven\'t given this enough thought to have a have thoughts on an API.

**pubsub.cljs**

We need to be able to dispatch and consume [PubSub](https://firebase.google.com/docs/reference/functions/providers_pubsub_) messages. The interface should be fairly simple here.We need some way to debug the production system.

We need some way to unify the types between the front-end, the NodeJS system and Clojure. The JSON-Schemas can handle that or we can look at how Clojure.spec could fill that need.

Clojure will be in **Cloud Run.** We need to be able to deploy to dev, staging and prod environments. We use Terraform and Kacper is working on getting the core environment up but we\'ll need a Docker image so we can run the Clojure app.We have a Dropbox Paper doc that details one of the more complex workflows with [Github data](https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/Github-Fixes--BD8CTueARaw3vf~SGB6WZ3z3Ag-RSOIkhbSsIzzaZwBh62eA).

​

## 3. CI- Enable Github Actions.

We need to have a system for continuous checks and metrics on the code.

- **Code Coverage**. I\'ve used cloverage. It should output to Github Actions to stop the pipeline if the coverage level is low. To start the coverage will be set at 10% and we don\'t need to get 100% but should know what it\'s at.

​

- **Unit Test **framework. [Koacha](https://github.com/lambdaisland/kaocha) is my preferred but we can use whatever. We should be able to test any level of the stack whether that\'s just a single namespace, mocking the persistence layer (pubsub/firestore) or doing an E2E with the Firestore emulator.

​

- **Performance/Benchmarking tests**. Ideally this is for E2E testing with the local emulators. We need a reproducible environment in Github Actions to guard against slow methods. Koacha comes with a profiler option if we go with that.

​

- **Property-based tests**. We should have the basic structure to run this in Github Actions.

​

## 4. ProductionObservability on production.

We need to know what prod is doing, how fast/slow it\'s running and be able to tell Cloud Run to scale up/down. I\'ve use timbre and tufte previously. They can log out to Stackdriver and we can add dashboards around it. The other known option is to use GCP metric to send data directly.

## 5. Application Structure

Lastly is how we handle our business requirements. The initial goal was to have Event Sourcing using Clojure.spec to define the event messages and we can serialize to either EDN or JSON. Most of the Clojure work will be coming in from PubSub or Webhooks.
A8Vl4FLKAw2tsTSPc04l.author: 0ZpXmyPNYbWhd7yL4yM5oPfwoxn2
A8Vl4FLKAw2tsTSPc04l.title: Clojure

AGDFnEl4TE3nDhZXkbpX.description:
The right Sidebar is used to inspect the details of any selected object. The sidebar will change based on what element is selected but this requirement is only for the sprint details. Figma link: [https://www.figma.com/file/TuF1X0AlGCHB2MpGISrrHH/Tara-App-UI?node-id=994%3A0](https://www.figma.com/file/TuF1X0AlGCHB2MpGISrrHH/Tara-App-UI?node-id=994%3A0).

​

## General logic

- on page load and if nothing is selected the current sprint\'s details will be displayed.
- when selecting another sprint column, the sprint details will reflect the selected sprint

​

## Task Filter Redux Slice

- all filtering in the side panel affects a global, in-memory display filter
- build a redux slice called taskFilter but do not build the search box UI
- All filtering will remove and override any existing filters. There is one exception. The status & people filters on the sprint detail pane are a pair. I recommend having those be together in a React component. Selecting one of those options will blow out any other filter but users can have either one or both of those filters active.

​

## Sprint Name Header

1a. Editing the name only edits the selected sprint\'s name.

1b. Character Length: Sprint title has a min length of 2 and a max length of 13 characters.

1c. ++**Engineering Requirement:**++** We have current sprintName\'s over 13 charaters. We do not want to break those so the decoder length will remain at 80 for now. Since the alpha will not have editable sprintNames we will only cut the display text to be 13 charaters. No updates to the Typescript decoder at this point.**

​

## Sprint Description

**1. Read-only mode**

1a. Character Length: Sprint description defaults to an empty string with a max length of 140. No text formatting, just a basic input field.

1b. There should be 2 seperate components. One for reading and a seperate for editing. (Reuse same editing component for Task sidebar title editing)

​

**2. Editing mode**

2a. Edit Mode Character Count: count is only for the description for visual characters.

2b. DraftJS should be used in editing mode.

2c. This is a design system component. There needs to be props for the parent to configure which DraftJS plugins are enabled.

**2d. **++**Out of Scope**++**: Editing the sprint name is out of scope. It will be read-only.**

**2e. **++**Out of Scope:**++** No dotted underline for the edit box for alpha.**

**2f. **++**Out of Scope:**++** The editor component will only support editing 1 property at a time.**

2g. Placeholder: placeholder text will be in a light grey if no content is in the field.

2h. Errors: For all validation errors, delete the contents of Draft editor and display the placeholder with the error text in a red color.

2i. Errors: When the placeholder text is showing a red error, any keypress event will reset the placeholder to the default state.

2j. Buttons. Do not use the text buttons. The save button will be a checkmark. Cancel will be an \'x\'.

2k. Buttons. There is no disable state for the save button. Clicking save runs validation and display an error in the placeholder field if errors.

2l. Enter edit mode by clicking the pencil icon next to the Sprint Name. (Sprint Name is NOT editable)

​

**3. Toast**

3a. There will be NO toast when saving. 3.0 needs to reflect every action immediatly to users just like a native app. 

​

​

## Sprint Date & time module

- There is no edit functionality. Instead use the gear in the sprint column section to edit sprint cadences.
- Team sprint settings are:

​

`team.sprintSettings.durationWeeks: SprintDurationWeeks;`

`team.sprintSettings.endDay: WeekDay;`

`team.sprintSettings.endHours: Hours;`

`team.sprintSettings.timezone: Timezone(TZ database name);`

`team.sprintSettings.moveRemainingTasksTo: \'NextSprint\' | \'Backlog\';`

​

## Sprint Filtering module

++Radio button acceptance criteria:++

- Clicking on a radio button will filter all tasks displayed on the **selected** sprint only.
- Clicking on a selected radio button will disable the radio button selection.
- One radio button from each group can be selected
- After 1 or more radio buttons are selected the **reset** button will be enabled.
- The effort and count of completed vs uncompleted are only for the selected sprint.

​

++Ordering/display acceptance criteria:++

- People will be ordered by total effort
- Only users with tasks in the active sprint are shown in the list.
- When more than 5 people are shown it will add a show more button at the bottom of the list. The sprint filter section does not scroll.

​

++Filtering acceptance criteria:++

- All filtering will affect the TaskFilter slice in redux. People & Status is a single filter that will remove/override anything else in the task filter slice.
- Selecting a filter only affects the selected sprint. Also setting a filter must override any other global sprint filters. (Please build the sprint filter as a slice that multiple components can set)
- Selecting a new sprint does NOT change the filters. If the new sprint does not have a person filter than it is only removable by clicking the "reset" button.
- The reset button clears all filters. Reset is disabled when the sprint has no filters active.
- Note: Check Charlie pod\'s search reducer to see if we can integrate into that at a Redux level.

​

++Visual acceptance criteria: ++

- Todo color will be yellow everywhere. (figma update in progress)
- The People section is NOT multi-select. But clicking an active radio button will toggle active/inactive.

​

## Edit Sprint Gear

- Edit sprint gear clicking toggles the "Edit Sprint Settings" modal
- Editing the modal will update the active team document. When the team doc is updated the backend will be updating all active + future sprint start & end dates. For this reason please only send the action for the team doc update when the modal is closed and has new selections.
- The rest of the functionality aligns with the current version. Please do NOT edit the existing React component as it will be used in the live app.

## Activity section

++Display acceptance criteria:++

- Activity is the last 5 tasks/revisions of tasks that are included in the sprint.
- Only 3 properties will be displayed here: **effortLevel** changes, **sprint** changes and **status** changes.
- The activity section is NOT scrollable and NOT pagination. It\'s only the last 5 task revisions.
- ++**Edge Case: Tasks removed from a sprint**++. Tasks removed MUST show in the active list. In order to properly fetch this the query will need to search for taskRevisions collectionGroup for all taskRevisions that contain the sprintId.

​

Out of Scope:

• Tasks removed. The query is too costly so we will not support that type.

​

++Engineering recommendations:++

- A new redux query will need to be created but it should reuse the same post-parsing code in the TaskRevisions query.

​

## ++Out of Scope++

- We do NOT do any UI for the search/filter box at the bottom of the sprint page. BUT all filtering options MUST set the redux slice.
- Aggressively downscope any addtional types of revisions. This is the least important component. Let\'s get it done and move on to more critical work.

BY2e3xMOQ3DOY9iQAmKr.description:
Overview
--------

Currently when we sign on a new customer, we create an org manually in the DB. Also, we don\'t allow for an external user who signs up with Tara to create an org. This requirement captures the changes to allow an external user to create an org during sign up

**Use Case**: org creation/selection upon sign up

Design: [https://zpl.io/bP8Bkey](https://zpl.io/bP8Bkey)

When a new user signs up to use Tara:

1.  If the user\'s email domain matches an existing org that already is tied to that user\'s email domain, then the user should be shown that an org already exists, and therefore the user will join that org.
2.  If the user\'s email domain is a public one (e.g. @gmail.com, @yahoo.com), or if the email domain is not already tied to an existing org in Tara, then the user should be given the opportunity to create an org. If the email domain is not a public one (e.g. "@somecompany.com", we should indicate to that user during sign up that the org will be tied that domain - so that subsequent users with that domain will automatically join that org.
3.  If the user was invited by another user via Tara\'s invite system, then the invited user would automatically join that org. Note: the invitation should expire after 7 days

**User sign-up page**

Currently we have a sign-in page but not a sign-up page. This should be part of the flow for signing up

Design:

*   main sign-up page: [https://zpl.io/awXnrQM](https://zpl.io/awXnrQM)
*   email sign-up page: [https://zpl.io/aR7oqgv](https://zpl.io/aR7oqgv)[](https://zpl.io/awXnrQM)

**Note**

1.  Email verification should be done for users using basic auth (username password)
2.  Verify email first before continuing on onboarding flow and org creation

**Supporting multiple orgs**

In this iteration, we will not officially support a user accessing multiple orgs for any customer users. We may provide a way to switch org for us Tara internal users with tara.ai domain.

**Potential future enhancement**: we may allow an org to be tied to more than one domains to let users automatically join. e.g. if an org is tied to "@somecompany.com" and "@someco.co", then both jane@somecompany.com and julia@someco.co will automatically join this org when they sign up.

EAJizBBM9tvZxIOmb2lE.description:
Project goals: [https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ZYZS3NJgG1CFQcd7zvDYRYJZOBfheCItmzghUcDzg0w/edit](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ZYZS3NJgG1CFQcd7zvDYRYJZOBfheCItmzghUcDzg0w/edit)

​

# Tara Orchestrator

## Display Github CI status for a Tara Task

​

1. Update the express router in NodeJS to accept Github\'s webhook method **workflow\_run** (https://github.com/TARAAI/tara-js/blob/development/microservices/functions/src/integrations/github/webhook/index.ts#L118-L145)
2. Send a PubSub with the contents of the webhook.
3. Create a Cloud Run EventARC trigger for PubSub messages to trigger the Clojurescript entry point (https://cloud.google.com/run/docs/quickstarts/events#trigger-setup, @see attachment)
4. Workflow\_run will be send when a workflow is request & finished. (Github\'s Workflow\_run payload: https://docs.github.com/en/developers/webhooks-and-events/webhook-events-and-payloads#workflow\_run)
5. Ensure the workflow\_run payload is saved in Big Query. This should be setup in infrastructure similar to [Firestore extension](https://firebase.google.com/products/extensions/firestore-bigquery-export), not in code.
6. Once the payload is saved we need to pull the details and associate to Tara data.
7. \* Get workflow details
8. \* Get all jobs for a workflow and the status of each job. When fetching be aware that Cloud Run timeouts can stop execution if it runs too long or too many fetches are needed.
9. \* Workflow have associated task(s) via commits, PRs or branches. Use those 3 types of IDs to query the database. When task(s) associations are found we should update those tasks with the CI Status.
0. \* CI Status to be appended to a task the details of the latest run. This should be per-job having the **name, start-time, finish-time and the result.**
1. \* Ensure the types package is updated with the new data points that will be exposed.
2. \* If required write a database migration to update existing data to the new format.

​

The end result is to have the relative tasks updated with the job information.

    interface CIJob {

   name: string; // the job name 

   id: string; // job id from the service (for github this is the check_run id)

   startTime: Timestamp;

   endTime: Timestamp | null;

   result: \'pass\' | \'fail\' | null;

}




tasks.ciJob = the_latest_job_that_failed_or_is_running

​

​

Workflow\_run webhook payload: https://docs.github.com/en/developers/webhooks-and-events/webhook-events-and-payloads#workflow\_run

Get Workflow details: https://docs.github.com/en/rest/reference/actions#get-a-workflow-run

Get Workflow job: https://docs.github.com/en/rest/reference/actions#list-jobs-for-a-workflow-run

​

**Out of Scope:**

- No need to fetch PRs, branches or commits. They should already be ingested via the NodeJS server
- No need to use PRs, branches or commits to associate them to a Tara task

​

​

​

​

​

F5r5w2TjlGYoOdTWcr0W.title: User Admin and Access Control
F5r5w2TjlGYoOdTWcr0W.description:
This requirement describes the user management functions.

Overview
--------

When a company uses Tara, that company would need to be able to control access to certain admin functionalities to ensure that the instance is properly managed.

User Roles and Capabilities
---------------------------

There are two roles that we will enable in this iteration, and they will not be customizable.

1\. **Admin**: the role that gives a user the ability to administer and manage her org’s Tara instance

Capabilities

*   Has access to all the features in Tara
*   Have access to all of her org’s users’ data
*   Can manage users: deactivate and reactivate users, change users’ roles
*   Can manage integrations - add / remove integrations with external systems
*   Can manage every aspect of the instance for that org: \[Future\] Delete the org and all the data associated with that org

Considerations

*   There must be at least one user that is an Admin per org
*   There can be more than one user can be an Admin.
*   Only Admins can assign Admin roles to another user

2\. **User**: general user role

Capabilities

*   All other functionalities not specific to the Admin roles can be considered fully available for Users role.
*   User with "User role" will still see the user list but won\'t have the ability to change other users\' role.

Considerations

*   When an org already exists, when a user joins that org for the first time, that user is automatically assigned User role. An Admin can change that User’s role into an Admin role

**Note**: these user roles are distinct from the user’s function - e.g. product manager, engineer, designer - which is set during user onboarding and does not affect access control.

User Role Lifecycle
-------------------

**Example**

1.  When a user - Jane - is the first user to sign up to use Tara for her organization, she is automatically assigned the role of Admin.
2.  Jane has the ability to invite other users - Peter and John. They are automatically assigned User role.
3.  Jane has the ability to change roles to Admin for one or both of them. Say Peter has been made an Admin.
4.  Peter, as an Admin, can change Jane’s role to User.
5.  With only User role - not Admin - Jane and John would only have read capability to the user list and cannot change any user’s role.

UI
--

Modify the user list to accommodate for the use cases and requirements describe above. Design spec: [https://zpl.io/aBD94KL](https://zpl.io/aBD94KL)[](https://zpl.io/VDdBJ73)
F5r5w2TjlGYoOdTWcr0W.author: LCu96CcgYjQz7tEYOi5J1CfMwIv2

FWMMCnFcvVqb7ln0FoH7.title: Filter-Search on Sprint Planning page
FWMMCnFcvVqb7ln0FoH7.description:
## Overview

**Central problem:** As teams continue to grow with Tara, the number of tasks will increase. When there are a large number of tasks, it is easy to miss putting critical tasks onto the upcoming sprint.

​

Having a way to easily find the tasks to load the sprints is essential to helping Product Managers and Engineering Leads to build a solid sprint plan. Here, we capture the requirements for a Filter-Search functionality on the Sprint Planning page.

​

## Concept

The Filter-Search functionality is about surfacing up the right tasks quickly on the sprint planning page so that the user can see whether the right tasks have been loaded onto the sprints or if they are still in the backlog.

​

It is \*NOT\* a universal search functionality.

​

## Designs

Here\'s the link to the designs: [https://zpl.io/beQPBdp](https://zpl.io/beQPBdp)

​

## Requirements

1. User can search by words on task and requirement title
2. User can search by labels on a task
3. When multiple search terms and labels are combined, AND condition is applied and further narrows the results
4. The results are highlighted on the sprint planning page, and the user can drag those results across sprint columns/backlog

​

## Questions

1. What about searching by Task-ID?
2. What about searching by GitHub repo?

​

## Out of scope

In this iteration, the following are out of scope

1. Searching for tasks that are not shown on the sprint planning page
2. Search for words in description or comments

​

## Acceptance

1. A user types in a word on the search bar and the app filters for the tasks and requirements titles that contain the word
2. The user adds another word and the system further filters

​
FWMMCnFcvVqb7ln0FoH7.author: LCu96CcgYjQz7tEYOi5J1CfMwIv2

FdGcehQw8vePJQiDrw5j.description:
Monetization Phased Rollout

Deadline for Merge: April 30th

​

![image](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/tara-cloud.appspot.com/o/orgs%2Ftara-ai%2Frequirements%2FFdGcehQw8vePJQiDrw5j%2Fimage-6581e224-b802-4292-9069-4276d9c9242b.png?alt=media&token=9f4b3322-c30b-40fb-9f05-cda7577d2036)

​

Problem: As we venture into rolling out monetization in the upcoming months. Our plan is to start converting some our early users onto paid plans. For this to happen we will need to implement a system to handle payments and save subscription information into firestore.

​

Solution: In order to process payments, we will be using Stripe and its hosted checkout flows and APIs to process the payments.

​

**Conversion Flow:**

This is the process which we will follow from start to finish when it comes to converting workspaces into paid plans.

​

1. Iba, Syed and Cisco will be getting on calls with customers to show them our pricing plans that will be hosted on figma or the marketing site. We will run them through features and price test with a selected subset of workspace users.
2. If the workspace that we have sold to and converted agrees to pay on a annual or monthly plan, we need to be able to activate a payments and billing page for the workspace. We want to be able to do this by having the the billing and payment pages behind a feature flag.
3. When the feature flag is turned on, the user will see an "Upgrade" badge on the top nav bar. Upon clicking the button, the user will be taken to a payments page with route "[app.tara.ai/name-of-the-workspace/upgrade](https://app.tara.ai/name-of-the-workspace/upgrade)" , _Example Design _[https://www.figma.com/file/vBZlvyxbxJY3dpJcidHZ6a/Monetization?node-id=412%3A26840](https://www.figma.com/file/vBZlvyxbxJY3dpJcidHZ6a/Monetization?node-id=412%3A26840)
4. This page will have an image of the pricing plans on the top and a single next button to initiate the stripe hosted checkout
5. Clicking on the next button will take you to Stripes Hosted Checkout Flow which opens in modal. Stripes Hosted Checkout flow will have all the default UI components and functionality needed to process the payment
6. At this point we want to pass the number of users in the workspace into stripe. This should be handled on the backend through a read only collection possibly.
7. Once the user successfully pays, the user will be redirected to a new tab we will create called Billing with the route [https://app.tara.ai/tara-ai/team-tara/workspace?tab=billing](https://app.tara.ai/tara-ai/team-tara/workspace?tab=billing)

​

**Discussion for Point 7:**

​

`Once the user successfully pays, the user will be redirected to a new tab we will create called Billing with the route`[`https://app.tara.ai/tara-ai/team-tara/workspace?tab=billing`](https://app.tara.ai/tara-ai/team-tara/workspace?tab=billing)

​

@tara-user-o4yyzJztJzg546ggMrWBjMX2dyw2 _Cisco here: I\'m not sure that we need a new tab. Let me take a stab at what the design would look like but I\'m averse to adding another tab. This is how we ended up with UX that was overly complicated. we should be pushing every workspace to upgrade, so that general workspace tab should have both the opportunity to upgrade and the manage billing. Let me have a look and I\'ll drop in some designs to show you what I\'m thinking._

​

@tara-user-BsKw5inAG8QDkMKg1JCqiAS9rKa2 _Comment from Syed: We can either put that in a tab or give it, its own page. I just wanted to give a space to redirect the user to after the payment was successful, the equivalent of a thank you page. So the thought was that a place where they can see the subscription active would be great._

​

_Stretch Goal_

1. **(Stretch Goal)** The billing page will show the name of subsciption selected for the workspace and if its active, the number of users its active for, it will show the next billing date for the subscription along with a cancellation button. These are all accessible through the stripe API.

​

**Stripe Documentation**

Example of Stripe Hosted Checkout [**https://checkout.stripe.dev/**](https://checkout.stripe.dev/)

​

Stripe Docs for Hosted Checkout [https://stripe.com/docs/payments/checkout](https://stripe.com/docs/payments/checkout)

​

**How to interact with the Stripe API using Stripe Checkout**

[https://stripe.com/docs/billing/subscriptions/checkout](https://stripe.com/docs/billing/subscriptions/checkout) this link has a step by step example on how to implement stripe checkout for subscriptions.

​

​

**Flow Block Diagram**

[**https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1RXe9vWE5dFdq4h46p1PRcIfc8Hnbv2XWDpCdNykL27M/edit#slide=id.p**](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1RXe9vWE5dFdq4h46p1PRcIfc8Hnbv2XWDpCdNykL27M/edit#slide=id.p)

​

**Note: **We will either need to make a new terms of service page or update our current terms-of-use page to include purchase information.

GNZD1Zu7yLvNTNDaYWcQ.title: Commenting Inline
GNZD1Zu7yLvNTNDaYWcQ.description:
## Term definitions: 

1. **Highlight** - a single, continous range of text. It can span multiple paragrahs and display elements like images and code blocks.

2. **Thread** - a group of comment. One-to-Many; one Thread can be linked to multiple highlights. A Thread can be resolved or open.

3. **Comment** - a single block of text, owned by a single person, inside of a thread.

​

## Edge cases to consider:

**1. Selection.**

**1a. Selection.** Select a range and save it as a highlight with a thread with a single comment.

**1b. Select existing highlight.** Select a range inside an existing highlight and add a new thread.

​

**2. Copying.**

**2a. Copy Highlight. **Copy text that includes a highlight.

**2b. Copy highlight that contains a highlight. **Copy text that includes highlights inside of highlights.

**2c. Pasting highlight inside of highlight. **Copying a highlight and pasting elsewhere then editing the copy in one of the highlight.

​

**3. Deletion.**

**3a. Delete internal characters.** Delete internal characters shrinks the range but still is linked to a thread.

**3b. Delete characters at the end/beginning.** Delete at the end/start of a range shrinks the highlight but keeps the link to the thread.

**3c. Deleting all characters.** Deleting all characters in a highlight (when no other highlights linked) will resolve the thread. 

**3d. Undo deletion.** Crtl+z will bring the highlight back and open the thread again.

​

**4. Pasting. **

**4a. Pasting partial highlight.** Pasting a chunk of text that include a highlight should associate the new range to the existing thread. Pasting multiples should assocciate to all the related threads.

**4b. Pasting a highlight inside a highlight.** Pasting a range that includes a highlight into another highlight. In Google Docs, this is break up the orginal highlight into 2 highlights which are both linked to the thread.

​

**5. Clicking.**

**5a. Click Highlight.** Clicking on a range that has a highlight actives the linked Thread.

**5b. Click Thread/Comment.** Clicking a thread, or comment in a thread, will scroll to the closest highlight. If multiple highlight the closest one in view is the one to show.

​

**6. Active State.**

6a.** Multi/Single active.** Only one thread can be active at a time. Multiple highlights will be active when a single thread is active.

6b. **Scope.** Active state is a local, but sharable via URL encoding. URL should add `#comment={commentId}`

6c. **Cold Boot. **When cold boot and navigating to a page with an active comment in the URL, Draft should scroll to see the highlight.

​

**7. Cursor.**

**7a. Cursor.** When the keyboard arrow keys move the cursor to be inside a highlight, it should activate the thread.

**7b. Cursor Range.** When using the keyboard to shift + arrow to expand the range, if a single highlight is included it should activate the thread. When multiple highlights are in the range it should deactive all threads.

**7c. Deactive.** Clicking to move the cursor to a non-highlighted section of text will deactive the thread and remove the state from the URL.

​

​

## Out of scope (not handled in Google Docs):

- With multiple highlights to a single thread there is no way to disassociate a single highlight to a thread.  

​

## Items to avoid (as much as possible):

- **No Persisence format changes. **The persisence format of draft editor text. It\'s currently Markdown. Ideally we try not to question this for the purpose of comments.

- **No Markdown Pipeline. **Markdown pipeline might need to be updated.

- **Consider bi-directional link.** Github issues markdown linked to tasks. Since Markdown is bi-directly linked to Github we should NOT include any comments in github.

​

## Data Model Features

**Assumptions**

- Want to load all active comments for a single document (either a task or requirement)

- Want to load all active comments that includes a single user. This is across all documents for a workspace. (Firestore FE client does not support collection groups)

- When a thread changes, want to push notifications to people on that thread. 

- Google comments do not sort, nor sort, when a comment is updated. Most likely they don\'t track updated at. 

- Highlight ranges are one-to-one with the document but don\'t matter for the comment. (Meaning comments can be in notifications or on the home page or an inbox. We don\'t always need to include the highlighted text with the thread but should have a way the backend could get it if needed)

**- Question: **Should editing a comment, highlight and document (either task or requirement) be in a single transaction? (Bobby: I assume it\'s not critical so we should assume any related linked documents are optional)

​

​

Type and front-end use cases

    interface Comment {

      threadId: millisecondsSinceEpoch; // note: allows for ordering by date

      owner: uid;

      mentions: uid[]; //_@default [];

      description: string; 

      createdAt: Timestamp;

      document: documentId;

      collection: collectionName;

      deletedAt: Timestamp | null; //_@default null;

      resolved: boolean: //_@default false; // note: when a thread is resolved, all comments get marked as resolved=true;

    }

     

    const getCommentsForDoc = (orgId, documentId, resolved=false) => ({

      collection: `/orgs/${orgId}/comments`,

      where: [[\'document\', \'==\', documentId], [\'deletedAt\', \'==\', null], [\'resolved\', \'==\', resolved]],

      orderBy: [[threadId, \'desc\'], [createdAt, \'desc\']]

    }); 

    // This would do ordering 100% via Firestore. get comments ordered by oldest thread, then comments by oldest to newest 

    // This structure would not support ordering by which comment shows first in a document. If that\'s a need once the doc\'s highlights are loaded they can order by range and load threads it wants first.

    ​

    const getCommentsForUser = (orgId, userId, resolved=false) =>  ({

      collection: `/orgs/${orgId}/comments`,

      where: [[\'owner\', \'==\', userId], [\'mentions\', \'array-contains\', userId], [\'resolved\', \'==\', resolved]],

      orderBy: [[threadId, \'desc\'], [createdAt, \'desc\']]

    });

    ​

    ​

    ​

    // Highlights are not docs, not searchable. They are a standard fragment inside another doc.

    // Note: Range should be translated to post-markdown range so the backend could translate markdown to richText and include the highlight in an email to others on the thread

    // Note: ThreadId will pull up multiple comments, will be gated to a single workspace

    // Note: Every save update to a doc must include all range updates. Even still this is only updating a single document.

    // Limitation call-out: When loading a doc we can\'t know if a highlight should be shown or not. Must load a single comment to see it\'s it\'s resolved. Could also duplicate the resolve flag in the highlight, but that\'s a transaction. I\'d lean on the side of avoiding it but maybe it\'s ok to add resolved on a highlight.

    interface Highlight {

      range: [start, end]; 

      threadId: threadId; 

    }

    ​

    interace Task {

     // ...

     highlights: Highlight[];

    }

    ​

    interace Requirement {

     // ...

     highlights: Highlight[];

    }

​

​

Backend use cases

    .onCommentWrite ;; send a notifaction to all others on a thread

    (->>

      (<! (query {:group \'comments\' :where [\'threadId\' \'==\' comment.threadId]}))

      (map #(conj (:mentions %) (% :owner)))

      (flatten)

      (hash-set)

      (remove #(= % (:owner comment)))

      (put-comment-notification))

    ​

    ;; NOTE: ideally the highlight range data is described in the markdown copy so that can be included in a Slack message or email notification

​

​

Overview
========

We are making changes to the login and sign up screens to enhance the user onboarding experience.

The designs are here: https://zpl.io/aR7oqAn

The test plan is here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1JboimI6SuPdWjzHdidAd3pXA18dwX1gvA9g5GWEWQD8/edit#gid=0

Important Note
--------------

Firebase does not seem to provide much flexibility for the login/signup UI elements, and therefore the implementation does not need to be completely identical to the designs on Zeplin, so long as the core functionalities and navigations work as described.

Core use cases
==============

1.  A new user needs to be able to sign up for Tara, using Google account, Github, or Email.
2.  An existing user needs to be able to log into Tara and access an org that the user has permission accessing.
3.  A new user for an org that has not previously enabled Github integration should be prompted to enable Github integrations for the org.
4.  A user would arrive at the Homepage after login is successful.

(Draft worksheet: [https://docs.google.com/document/d/1pvJ7OnUHX5TRKMN54OUDFxfmIeTEVV3IWKcr0AIA3Co/edit#](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1pvJ7OnUHX5TRKMN54OUDFxfmIeTEVV3IWKcr0AIA3Co/edit#))

**Conversations/demos kick-off: April 26th, 2021**

## Plan:

​

April: Hit 10 workspaces upgraded; these 10 workspaces should be automatically charged when they add additional users.

May: Hit 60 workspaces upgraded; engineering/product work to create flows inside the product to make it compelling for teams to upgrade on their own.

June: Hit 100 workspaces upgraded; make decision on launching monetization June 1 or July 1

​

July: monetization fully launched, with 100 workspaces already upgraded.

**June 1 onwards; ie money in account through Stripe.**

​

​

## Wave 1 in April: 20 workspaces upgraded

​

- Reach out to 10-20 workspace owners, focusing first on workspaces in the US.
- Goal: Close 20 workspaces, with 200 users, by end of April. **Expected ARR: $19,200**
- Understand users per workspace and have a list ready in a google sheet. @tara-user-o4yyzJztJzg546ggMrWBjMX2dyw2 to supply number of users in these workspaces. I also need to know the number of workspaces per company - this is all helpful info to have on hand as we sell.
- Schedule 45 minute zoom call, alternatively have a link at the ready for the form signup so the workspace owner can activate on their own if they don\'t hop on a zoom call.
- Need a figma link or a URL at the ready to show monthly vs annual plan on the zoom call. @tara-user-BsKw5inAG8QDkMKg1JCqiAS9rKa2 to help.
- Can also test plans on the go and have various versions of each plan in terms of feature sets.
- We should have 2 plans at the ready ($8/mo and $12/mo). It can be premium workspace vs growing business (growing business plan would have all TIM and CI/CD features).
- Offer: first 2 months are free if signup by X date. Chargebee or billing needs to start at Y date (for eg July 1), can use Stripe for this possibly?
- Have 1-2 levers to push/pull and some level of data on number of tasks/sprints for these workspaces. These are available in KPIs in leaderboard. The idea here could be to test if we just mention that X number of repos are free, X number of tasks free, etc.
- If Chargebee is used, need a way to connect a workspace to chargebee or to stripe, so that the workspace is automatically billed/charged when a new user is added. This may require engineering intervention, and ideally the workspace is auto charged
- When a workspace "pays", we either manually update the workspace to "premium" through a feature flag, or we do an automatic upgrade. For now, a premium workspace has a denotion at the top with a premium tag. Do we also need another tag for "autopilot" or "business" plan at the higher level ie $12/mo?
- Next step would be to roll out the "free" tag to all workspaces, I would hold off on doing this until we have a clearer picture of what is included in a free vs premium workspace and once we have some headway on the engineering/features side in May.
- **The goal here is to test and iterate on the pricing plans as we talk to users and get feedback, or hear negative responses on upgrading to premium. This is where I have less intel on how to proceed if someone declines and has 2 or more teams. ie do we "downgrade" their account so they can only have 1 team? What\'s the dis-incentive here?**

​

- Script to use:

​

Hi first name,

​

I\'m really excited to share that we are exclusively presenting premium workspaces to a handful of users, to activate. I\'d love to hop on a call and show you the upcoming features in premium workspaces.

​

OR

​

Hi First name,

​

I\'m really excited to share that we are exclusively presenting premium workspaces to a handful of users, to activate. Premium workspaces are for 2+ teams in your current workspace, and include several other features that are upcoming over the next few weeks. Our data shows that Alto has activated more than 2 teams, and would benefit from upgrading to a premium workspace.

​

​

​

## Wave 2 in May: 100 workspaces upgraded

- Goal: Close 100 workspaces, with 1000 users, by end of June. **Expected ARR: $96,000**
- In the meantime, engineering and product work to make it easy and compelling for teams to upgrade inside the product itself. This is in May and June.
- ​

## Wave 3 in June: 200 workspaces upgraded

​

​

## Official launch: July

​

HUySaJUWJPsCHSspdrta.title: Improving the behavior and interactions of filtered lists
HUySaJUWJPsCHSspdrta.author: LCu96CcgYjQz7tEYOi5J1CfMwIv2
HUySaJUWJPsCHSspdrta.description:
## Overview

In this requirement, we capture updates to how Tara handles list of records, in particular what happens when the query results change.

Examples of lists of records where results can change

- List of tasks within a requirement which can be filtered
- List of requirements filtered with search
- Task gallery navigation

Scenarios of query result changes

1. A record added - examples
2. In a requirement, while the list of tasks has been filtered, a new task has been added that fits the filter criteria.
3. A record removed - examples

Expected behavior

1. A record is added to the list
2. A record is removed from the list

​

​

**Additional problems with filtered results:**

1. Filter tasks in requirement.
2. From the filtered list view, try to change **sprint** of filtered tasks or **status**.

Result:

Sprint or status is not updated for the user. For user to see the results of update, he needs to remove filters or open modal.
